articles.headline: Monks Are Silenced, and for Now, Internet Is, Too
articles.snippet: After smuggled images jeopardized their crackdown on demonstrators, Myanmar’s generals cut off the Internet.
articles.abstract: After smuggled images jeopardized their crackdown on demonstrators, Myanmar’s generals cut off the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Oct. 3 — It was about as simple and uncomplicated as shooting demonstrators in the streets. Embarrassed by smuggled video and photographs that showed their people rising up against them, the generals who run Myanmar simply switched off the Internet.

articles.headline: On Stump, Low-Key Thompson Stirs Few Sparks
articles.snippet: As Fred D. Thompson campaigned in Iowa this week, he was something other than the dynamic presence some Republicans have been yearning for.
articles.abstract: As Fred D. Thompson campaigned in Iowa this week, he was something other than the dynamic presence some Republicans have been yearning for.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEVADA, Iowa, Oct. 3 — Twenty-four minutes after he began speaking in a small restaurant the other day, Fred D. Thompson brought his remarks to a close with a nod of his head and an expression of thanks to Iowans for allowing him to “give my thoughts about some things.”

articles.headline: Keeping Arteries Cleared and the Courts Clogged
articles.snippet: With billions in profits at stake, stent makers are embroiled in lawsuits in the U.S. and abroad over patents.
articles.abstract: With billions in profits at stake, stent makers are embroiled in lawsuits in the U.S. and abroad over patents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Why would a company argue in court that its medical product is dangerous, even as it plays down the risks in public?

articles.headline: North Koreans Agree to Disable Nuclear Facilities
articles.snippet: The deal sets a timetable for North Korea to disable all of its nuclear facilities in return for economic aid.
articles.abstract: The deal sets a timetable for North Korea to disable all of its nuclear facilities in return for economic aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  North Korea has agreed to disable all of its nuclear facilities by the end of the year, in a move that the Bush administration hailed as a diplomatic victory that could serve as a model for how to deal with Iran, which has defied American efforts to rein in its nuclear ambitions.

articles.headline: In Ballot Fight, California Gets a Taste of ’08
articles.snippet: An initiative on electoral votes has become a battleground for Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
articles.abstract: An initiative on electoral votes has become a battleground for Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 — Ballot measures in California have long been proxies for local politicians’ hopes and dreams — just ask Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who rode a recall petition to the Statehouse.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Raymond Hernandez

articles.headline: Lean Crop of Dollars
articles.snippet: Despite intense lobbying, growers of fruits, vegetables and tree nuts are falling short in their goals to secure government payments in the farm bill now being debated on Capitol Hill.
articles.abstract: Despite intense lobbying, growers of fruits, vegetables and tree nuts are falling short in their goals to secure government payments in the farm bill now being debated on Capitol Hill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With Americans eating bad diets and getting fatter by the year, the nation’s produce industry made a bold political calculation. Surely, farmers thought, the government could be talked into supporting crops like New Jersey tomatoes, Michigan apples and California spinach.

articles.headline: In Facebook, Investing in a Theory
articles.snippet: Thousands of software developers are creating features for Facebook, the fast-growing social network, many hoping to strike it rich alongside Facebook’s own employees.
articles.abstract: Thousands of software developers are creating features for Facebook, the fast-growing social network, many hoping to strike it rich alongside Facebook’s own employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 — The Facebook frenzy is spreading.

articles.headline: For Baltimore, Housing Slump Slows a Revival
articles.snippet: The slowdown in the housing market is endangering the city’s efforts to transition away from manufacturing.
articles.abstract: The slowdown in the housing market is endangering the city’s efforts to transition away from manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Colorful banners, draped across buildings like giant flags, urge people driving through Baltimore’s rebuilt downtown neighborhoods to move into the new condos and apartments inside. “Sophisticated Urban Living W/Garage and Gated Off-Street Parking” one sign declares in the long campaign to gentrify the central city.

articles.headline: 2 Executives Are Ousted at Merrill
articles.snippet: The firings signal that the aggressive push by Merrill’s chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, into riskier markets  may be coming back to haunt him.
articles.abstract: The firings signal that the aggressive push by Merrill’s chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, into riskier markets  may be coming back to haunt him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merrill Lynch, facing the prospect of a major write-down from its exposure to the sinking mortgage market, dismissed two senior executives in its fixed-income division yesterday.

articles.headline: Wishing and Hoping for Clinton’s Seat
articles.snippet: No subject seems to set New York Democrats’ hearts aflutter these days like the possible opening of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s seat in the United States Senate.
articles.abstract: No subject seems to set New York Democrats’ hearts aflutter these days like the possible opening of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s seat in the United States Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sure, the legislative races next year are a concern, and there are many thorny issues to tackle in Albany. But no subject seems to set New York Democrats’ hearts aflutter these days like the possible opening of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s seat in the United States Senate, which would create a rare chance for one of them to rise.

articles.headline: Laptop With a Mission Widens Its Audience
articles.snippet: A low-cost computer intended to aid children in poor countries will soon be on sale here, for two weeks only.
articles.abstract: A low-cost computer intended to aid children in poor countries will soon be on sale here, for two weeks only.
articles.lead_paragraph: In November, you’ll be able to buy a new laptop that’s spillproof, rainproof, dustproof and drop-proof. It’s fanless, it’s silent and it weighs 3.2 pounds. One battery charge will power six hours of heavy activity, or 24 hours of reading. The laptop has a built-in video camera, microphone, memory-card slot, graphics tablet, game-pad controllers and a screen that rotates into a tablet configuration.
